content.raw: Wouldn't a "square frustum" always have aspect ratio == 1?
content.html: Wouldn't a "square frustum" always have aspect ratio == 1?

content.raw: Not sure if it might be worth it to mention here that the distance will be negative is the point is in the negative normal side. Often distance refers to a positive value.
content.html: Not sure if it might be worth it to mention here that the distance will be negative is the point is in the negative normal side. Often distance refers to a positive value.

content.raw:
I think this should be `nearWidth`, right?

~~~
double nearWidth = nearHeight * this->dataPtr->aspectRatio;
~~~
content.html:
I think this should be nearWidth, right?

double nearWidth = nearHeight * this->dataPtr->aspectRatio;

content.raw: The description of `fov` says "This value represents the horizontal angle.", so shouldn't it be used to compute width instead of height?
content.html: The description of fov says "This value represents the horizontal angle.", so shouldn't it be used to compute width instead of height?

content.raw:
If I didn't get anything wrong, the plane offset for the near and far planes are wrt the vertex while the offsets for the other 4 planes are being taken from the center. 

I think all planes should be described wrt the same point. And since all points have been transformed to the parent frame, maybe all the distances should be taken from the origin (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0)? 

![frustum.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/dg5enz/images/601856391-frustum.png)
content.html:
If I didn't get anything wrong, the plane offset for the near and far planes are wrt the vertex while the offsets for the other 4 planes are being taken from the center.

I think all planes should be described wrt the same point. And since all points have been transformed to the parent frame, maybe all the distances should be taken from the origin (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0)?
